ðŸ’¡ choof | Go
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Managing files efficiently from the command line.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Detailed File Info (size, creation/modification dates, permissions, hashes) â€¢ File Operations (delete, rename, open) â€¢ User-Friendly Interface â€¢ Keyboard Shortcuts
ðŸ“– Summary: Choof is a CLI tool for Linux that provides a user-friendly interface for viewing and managing file information. It allows users to inspect file details, delete, rename, and open files directly from the terminal using simple keybindings.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

âœ¨ regname | Rust
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Batch renaming files in a directory using a terminal-based interface.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Mass renaming of files â€¢ Terminal User Interface (TUI) â€¢ Interactive selection of files to rename â€¢ Pattern matching for file selection
ðŸ“– Summary: Regname is a Rust-based tool that provides a terminal user interface for mass renaming files. It allows users to interactively select files based on a pattern and rename them in batch, offering a convenient way to manage large numbers of files.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸš€ reaver-wps-fork-t6x | C
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Recovering WPA/WPA2 passphrases by exploiting vulnerabilities in Wi-Fi Protected Setup (WPS) implementations.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Brute-force attack against Wifi Protected Setup (WPS) registrar PINs â€¢ Recovery of WPA/WPA2 passphrases â€¢ Offline Pixie Dust attack â€¢ Bug fixes and new features compared to original Reaver â€¢ Compatibility with various access points and WPS implementations
ðŸ“– Summary: The reaver-wps-fork-t6x repository is a community-maintained fork of the Reaver tool, designed for brute-forcing WPS PINs to recover WPA/WPA2 passphrases. It includes bug fixes, new features like the Pixie Dust attack, and aims to be a robust solution for testing the security of WPS implementations.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

âœ¨ CloudFail | Python
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Discovering the real IP addresses of servers hidden behind Cloudflare.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Misconfigured DNS scan using DNSDumpster.com â€¢ Crimeflare.com database scan â€¢ Bruteforce scan over 2500 subdomains â€¢ Tor support for anonymized scanning
ðŸ“– Summary: CloudFail is a reconnaissance tool designed to uncover the original IP addresses of servers protected by Cloudflare. It achieves this by employing techniques such as scanning for misconfigured DNS records, searching the Crimeflare.com database, and performing brute-force subdomain enumeration, optionally using Tor for anonymity.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸŒŸ pgdog | Rust
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Horizontal scaling of PostgreSQL databases with automatic sharding.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Load balancer with healthchecks and failover â€¢ Transaction pooling â€¢ Sharding with COPY command support â€¢ Logical replication â€¢ Runtime configuration
ðŸ“– Summary: PgDog is a Rust-based transaction pooler and logical replication manager designed for horizontal scaling of PostgreSQL. It offers features like load balancing, transaction pooling, and automatic sharding, enabling efficient management of numerous databases and connections. PgDog supports healthchecks, failover, and runtime configuration, ensuring high availability and adaptability.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸ”¥ RustPotato | Rust
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Privilege escalation on Windows systems by abusing SeImpersonatePrivilege.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ TCP-based Reverse Shell â€¢ Indirect NTAPI
ðŸ“– Summary: RustPotato is a Rust-based privilege escalation tool that implements the GodPotato technique. It leverages DCOM and RPC to exploit SeImpersonatePrivilege and gain SYSTEM privileges, featuring a TCP-based reverse shell and indirect NTAPI calls for token manipulation.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸ”¥ tbls | Go
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Documenting databases in a CI-friendly manner.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Automatic database documentation in GFM format â€¢ Single binary for CI-friendliness â€¢ Support for many databases â€¢ Database linting capabilities
ðŸ“– Summary: tbls is a CI-friendly tool written in Go that automatically documents databases in various formats, including GFM. It supports a wide range of databases and functions as a linter, ensuring database structure quality. Its single-binary design makes it ideal for continuous integration environments.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

âœ¨ shattered-pixel-dungeon | Java
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Playing and modifying a traditional roguelike game.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Open-source â€¢ Roguelike dungeon crawler â€¢ Randomized levels and enemies â€¢ Hundreds of items to collect and use â€¢ Cross-platform (Android, iOS, Desktop)
ðŸ“– Summary: Shattered Pixel Dungeon is an open-source, cross-platform roguelike game based on Pixel Dungeon. It features randomized levels, enemies, and items, providing a unique gameplay experience each time. The repository provides the source code for users to play, modify, and compile the game for various platforms.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source

ðŸŒŸ squish | TypeScript
ðŸŽ¯ Primary Use Case: Batch browser-based image compression and format conversion.
âœ¨ Key Features: â€¢ Browser-based compression â€¢ Batch processing â€¢ Multiple image format support (AVIF, JPEG, JPEG XL, PNG, WebP) â€¢ Quality adjustment â€¢ Format conversion
ðŸ“– Summary: Squish is a browser-based image compression tool that allows users to compress images in various formats (AVIF, JPEG, JPEG XL, PNG, and WebP) without server uploads. It supports batch processing, format conversion, and quality adjustment, leveraging WebAssembly for high-performance image optimization.
ðŸ”— Links: â€¢ View Project â€¢ Homepage ================ ðŸ”“ Open Source
